questions.text: The government should directly control key industries like steel, coal, and railways rather than privatizing them.
Direct Benefit Transfers (DBT) and welfare schemes like PM-KISAN are essential government responsibilities, not optional programs.
Private companies should have minimal restrictions on hiring, firing, and labor practices.
The government should heavily regulate prices of essential commodities like food grains and fuel.
Infrastructure development (roads, electricity, water) is best handled by government agencies rather than private contractors.
The government should reduce its role in the economy and let market forces determine prices and production.
The government should actively intervene to eliminate social practices like untouchability and caste discrimination, even if it means overriding local traditions.
Religious institutions should manage their own affairs without government interference in matters like temple administration.
The state should regulate marriage practices (minimum age, dowry prohibition, inter-caste marriage promotion) to transform social norms.
Traditional social and cultural practices should be preserved without government intervention.
The government should use education to actively promote progressive social values and challenge traditional hierarchies.
Laws against cow slaughter and similar religious-cultural regulations are appropriate uses of state power.
Reservation in jobs and education for Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes should be maintained.
OBC (Other Backward Classes) reservations should be continued as they address historical disadvantages.
Merit alone should determine college admissions and government jobs, regardless of caste background.
The government should track caste data in census to better target welfare programs.
Reservation policies have become outdated and should be replaced with income-based criteria only.
Political reservations for women and marginalized groups in Parliament and state assemblies should be expanded.
Minority communities should have the right to run their own educational institutions with autonomy.
A Uniform Civil Code (same personal laws for all religions) should be implemented across India.
Special provisions for minority religions (like Haj subsidies or Waqf boards) should be maintained.
The government should actively protect religious minorities from majoritarian pressures.
Special protections and rights for specific communities create divisions and should be minimized.
India should prioritize a unified national identity over accommodating diverse group identities.
Government benefits should prioritize communities that have historically supported a party or leader.
Welfare schemes should have strict eligibility criteria applied equally to everyone, regardless of their community.
Local MLAs and MPs should have discretionary funds to distribute as they see fit for their constituencies.
Ration cards and subsidies should be allocated based on objective income criteria verified by technology, not local recommendations.
It's natural for politicians to take care of their own community's needs first when distributing government resources.
Government contracts and jobs should be awarded through transparent, competitive processes without regard to personal connections.
It's acceptable for politicians to favor their caste or community members when distributing government jobs and contracts.
Personal connections and recommendations should play no role in accessing government services and benefits.
Politicians should be evaluated based on their party's overall policy performance, not what they deliver to their specific community.
Bureaucrats should follow rules strictly even if it means not being able to help someone from their own background.
A candidate from my own caste or community will naturally understand and serve my interests better than others.
Government welfare programs should be designed and implemented the same way everywhere, regardless of local community preferences.
